title: Vows and Valuations
shortSummary: Leviticus 27 outlines the laws regarding vows made to the Lord, including the valuation of persons, animals, houses, and fields dedicated to God. It emphasizes the holiness of devoted things and the procedures for redeeming or dedicating property, underscoring the principle of honoring commitments to God with integrity and reverence.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Wilderness Period after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The mediator who receives and communicates God's commandments to the Israelites, including the laws about vows in this chapter.

keyCharacters.name: The Priest
keyCharacters.description: The religious official responsible for valuing persons, animals, and property dedicated to the Lord and overseeing their redemption or consecration.

keyCharacters.name: The Children of Israel
keyCharacters.description: The covenant people who are instructed to follow the laws concerning vows and dedications to the Lord.

definitions.definition: A specific standard of weight and value used for silver in the temple, approximately 11.4 grams, used here to determine valuations.
A special year occurring every 50th year when land was returned to original owners and debts forgiven, symbolizing restoration and God's provision.
An item or person set apart completely for the Lord, which cannot be redeemed or sold but is considered most holy.
A tenth part of produce or livestock given to the Lord as an act of worship and obedience.

outline.heading: Valuation of Persons Vowed to the Lord
outline.description: God instructs Moses on how to estimate the value of persons who make a vow dedicating themselves to the Lord, with different valuations based on age, gender, and ability to pay, highlighting the seriousness and fairness in fulfilling vows.

outline.heading: Valuation and Redemption of Animals
outline.description: The chapter details the treatment of animals vowed to the Lord, distinguishing between clean and unclean beasts, and sets rules for their valuation and redemption, emphasizing holiness and the integrity of vows.

outline.heading: Sanctification and Redemption of Houses and Fields
outline.description: Instructions are given for dedicating houses and fields to the Lord, including how priests estimate their value, the conditions for redemption, and the impact of the year of Jubilee on land ownership, underscoring God's ownership of all property.

outline.heading: Rules Concerning Devoted Things and Tithes
outline.description: The chapter concludes with laws about the irrevocability of devoted things, the holiness of firstborn animals, and the proper handling of tithes, reinforcing the principle that what is dedicated to God is holy and must be treated accordingly.

outline.heading: Summary of the Commandments
outline.description: A closing statement affirming that these are the commandments given by the Lord to Moses for the children of Israel at Mount Sinai, emphasizing their divine authority.

application: Honor your commitments to God with seriousness and integrity, recognizing that vows are sacred and must be fulfilled according to His standards.
Trust in God's provision and justice by respecting His ownership over all things, including possessions and resources.
Practice generosity and obedience by faithfully giving tithes and offerings as acts of worship and acknowledgment of God's lordship.
Seek the guidance of spiritual leaders when making significant commitments to ensure they align with God's will and instructions.

keyVerses.text: And all the tithe of the land, whether of the seed of the land, or of the fruit of the tree, is the LORD'S: it is holy unto the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the principle that all tithes belong to God and are to be set apart as holy, underscoring the importance of faithful giving.

keyVerses.text: Notwithstanding no devoted thing, that a man shall devote unto the LORD of all that he hath, both of man and beast, and of the field of his possession, shall be sold or redeemed: every devoted thing is most holy unto the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes the irrevocable nature of dedicating something to God, teaching reverence and the seriousness of vows.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD spake unto Moses, saying,
keyVerses.significance: This opening verse establishes the divine origin and authority of the instructions that follow, reminding readers that these laws come directly from God.
